description: From Latin sexuālis, from sexus (“sex”); see sex.

adjectives.description: sexual (comparative more sexual, superlative most sexual)

entries.meaning: Arising from the fact of being male or female; pertaining to sex or gender, or to the social relations between the sexes. [from 17th c.]
examples: Women face sexual discrimination in the workplace.

entries.meaning: (biology) Capable of sexual reproduction; sexed, sexuate. [from 19th c.]
Pertaining to sexual intercourse or other intimate physical contact. [from 18th c.]
examples: Giving oral sex is my favorite sexual act.

entries.meaning: Characterised by sexual feelings or behaviour; possessing sexuality. [from 19th c.]
Pertaining to sexuality as a cultural phenomenon; relating to sexual behaviour or conduct. [from 19th c.]
(LGBT, of a person, rare) Experiencing sexual attraction; not asexual.
(obsolete) Pertaining to the female sex. [17th–19th c.]
(biology) A species which reproduces by sexual rather than asexual reproduction, or a member of such a species.
(LGBT) A person who experiences sexual attraction, a person who has interest in or desire for sex (especially as contrasted with an asexual).
